title: ASADA not immune to cyber attacks: CEO
text:
Australia's anti-doping agency boss David Sharpe says his organisation was not one of the agencies hacked by Russians this week, but admits it's not immune to cyber attacks.

Microsoft confirmed this week at least 16 sports anti-doping agencies around the world were attacked by the same Russians hackers who tried to infiltrate ASADA last year.

The attacks came in the wake of World Anti-Doping Agency giving Russia three weeks to explain how some of their athletes' failed drug tests had been erased from a critical data set.

Mr Sharpe confirmed his agency had successfully repelled the group known as Fancy Bear in 2018 but said they were not targeted in the most recent attacks.

The former Australian Federal Police assistant commissioner said cybersecurity was one of his major focuses after taking the ASADA top job in 2017.

"Coming out of the background I have around national security and cyber threats, that was one of my biggest priorities when I arrived here and we invested very heavily on our security platforms," Mr Sharpe told AAP.

"The processes we have now, we've taken all our data storage off-site and we're working with all the cybersecurity government agencies. We're also working with independent non-government agencies to actually test our systems regularly.

"Does that mean we're solid? It means we're good but does it mean we're 100 per cent? No.

"You're never completely safe from cyber attacks. It could be as simple as someone clicking on a link and we're done."

Mr Sharpe said ASADA was a target because the Russians are trying to "take the heat off" themselves by tarnishing a world-leading anti-doping agency.

"I know a lot of athletes might criticise doping in Australia but we hold ourselves to a very high standard on a global stage," he said.

"The benefit for them is they embarrass Australia and take the heat off other programs and we have to protect athletes from that the best we can.

"Any comments I make about this makes us a higher target but we're prepared for that and we've got to continue to be better every day."
